import pyspark.sql.functions as F
import pyspark.sql.types as T
from pyspark.ml.regression import LinearRegression
from pyspark.ml.regression import GeneralizedLinearRegression
from pyspark.ml.feature import VectorAssembler, StringIndexer, OneHotEncoder, FeatureHasher, Bucketizer
from pyspark.ml import Pipeline
from pyspark.sql.window import Window
from datetime import date, timedelta, datetime
from dateutil.relativedelta import relativedelta
from pyspark.sql import Row
from pyspark.sql.types import StructType, StructField, StringType
import itertools
import json

# Load usage source
cost_path = f'abfss://usage@{storageAccount}.dfs.core.windows.net/exports/monthly/ACMMonthlyActualCost/*/Extended_v3_ACMMonthlyActualCost_*.parquet'
cost_df = spark.read.format('parquet').load(cost_path)

# Only consider cost inside the defined lookback period
initial_date = datetime.now().date() - relativedelta(months=LOOKBACK_PERIOD)
cost_df = cost_df.where(F.col('Date') >= initial_date)

# Select appropriate columns
cost_df = cost_df.select('Date', *cost_columns, 'CostInBillingCurrency')
cost_df = cost_df.withColumn('Date', F.date_trunc('month', 'Date'))
cost_df = cost_df.groupBy('Date', *cost_columns).agg(F.sum('CostInBillingCurrency').alias('Cost')).orderBy('Date')

# Filter away latest month - as we predict cost per month, it will mess up future predictions
cost_df = cost_df.filter(F.col('Date') < F.concat(F.date_format(F.current_date(), 'yyyy'), F.lit('-'), F.date_format(F.current_date(), 'MM'), F.lit('-'), F.lit('01')))

# Only consider positive cost
cost_df = cost_df.where(F.col('Cost') >= 0)

# Replace null-values with string value
for col_name in cost_columns:
    cost_df = cost_df.withColumn(col_name, F.coalesce(F.col(col_name), F.lit('empty')))

generate_join_key = F.concat(*[F.concat(F.col(col_name), F.lit('.')) for col_name in cost_columns])
cost_df = cost_df.withColumn('CostJoinKey', generate_join_key)

# Ignore resources where cost is 0 in entire date range
cost_df = cost_df.withColumn("WindowSum", F.sum("Cost").over(Window.partitionBy('CostJoinKey')))
cost_df = cost_df.where(F.col("WindowSum") > 0).drop("WindowSum")

# Construct zero-fill dataframe
dates_df = cost_df.select('Date').distinct()
dimensions_df = cost_df.select(*cost_columns).distinct()
fill_df = dates_df.crossJoin(dimensions_df)

# Don't zero-fill for dates where we already have cost
fill_df = fill_df.subtract(cost_df.select("Date", *cost_columns))
fill_df = fill_df.withColumn('Cost', F.lit(0))

fill_df = fill_df.withColumn('CostJoinKey', generate_join_key)

# Zero-fill missing rows where resource doesn't have cost
cost_df = cost_df.union(fill_df)

# Get difference in latest and earliest cost
cost_df = cost_df.withColumn("LatestCost", F.last("Cost").over(Window.partitionBy('CostJoinKey')))
cost_df = cost_df.withColumn("EarliestCost", F.first("Cost").over(Window.partitionBy('CostJoinKey')))
cost_df = cost_df.withColumn("CostDiff", F.col("LatestCost") - F.col("EarliestCost")).drop("LatestCost", "EarliestCost")

# The cost of the previous row will be the main feature for the ML model
cost_df = cost_df.withColumn("PrevCost", F.lag("Cost", 1).over(Window.partitionBy('CostJoinKey').orderBy("Date")))

# Decompose the date into a integer columns for year and month (ML model will only handle number features)
cost_df = cost_df.withColumn("Year", F.year("Date"))
cost_df = cost_df.withColumn("Month", F.month("Date"))

# Remove null values
cost_df = cost_df.dropna(subset=["PrevCost", "CostDiff"])

# Add an additional bucket feature indicating the cost level (important to capture the dynamics of increasing vs diminishing costs)
# Create logarithmic scale bucket ranges
bucketizer_splits = [0] + [10 ** x for x in range(0, 6)] + [float("inf")]

# Apply bucketizer to dataframe to create cost bin feature column
bucketizer = Bucketizer(splits=bucketizer_splits, inputCol="PrevCost", outputCol="CostBin")
cost_df = bucketizer.transform(cost_df)

# Create structure of input and output values for model
assembler = VectorAssembler(inputCols=["Year", "Month", "PrevCost", "CostBin"], outputCol="features")

# Define the linear regression model parameters and pipeline configuration
glr = GeneralizedLinearRegression(featuresCol="features", labelCol="Cost", family="gaussian", link="identity")
pipeline = Pipeline(stages=[assembler, glr])

# Build linear regression model
pipeline_model = pipeline.fit(cost_df)

# Define and build the prediction horizon length in the number of months 
last_date = dates_df.agg(F.max('Date')).collect()[0][0]
future_dates = [last_date + relativedelta(months=i) for i in range(1, PREDICTION_INTERVAL + 1)]
## Forecast cost using linear regression model

# Find the latest cost for each feature set
latest_cost_window_spec = Window.partitionBy(*cost_columns).orderBy(F.desc("Date")).rowsBetween(Window.unboundedPreceding, Window.currentRow)
result = cost_df.select('Date', *cost_columns, *feature_columns, 'Cost', 'CostJoinKey')

# Create new dataframe structure containing all possible combinations of features and dates
date_df = spark.createDataFrame([(d,) for d in future_dates], ["Date"]).withColumn("Date", F.col("Date").cast(T.DateType()))
date_df = date_df.crossJoin(dimensions_df)

# Split date into months and years to match structure of the original dataFrame
date_df = date_df.withColumn("Year", F.year("Date"))
date_df = date_df.withColumn("Month", F.month("Date"))
date_df = date_df.withColumn('CostJoinKey', generate_join_key)

latest_cost_df = result \
    .withColumn("rank", F.row_number().over(latest_cost_window_spec)) \
    .where(F.col('rank') == 1) \
    .drop('Date', 'rank') \
    .withColumn('PrevCost', F.col('Cost')) \
    .select('CostJoinKey', 'PrevCost', 'CostDiff')

for current_date in future_dates:
    print(f'Start predicting for {current_date}')

    # Re-compute the CostBin feature as latest cost dataframe is updated in every iteration
    latest_cost_df = bucketizer.transform(latest_cost_df)

    # Only predict cost for the date in the current iteration
    current_df = date_df.where(F.col('Date') == current_date)

    # The cost value for each feature set (and for all dates) will be given by the latest known cost for that feature set
    current_df = current_df.join(latest_cost_df, 'CostJoinKey', 'left')

    # Predict cost using glr model
    prediction_df = pipeline_model.transform(current_df)
    prediction_df = prediction_df.withColumnRenamed('prediction', 'Cost')
    prediction_df = prediction_df.select('Date', *cost_columns, *feature_columns, 'Cost', 'CostJoinKey')

    # Set negative predictions to 0 as the model does not handle negative cost
    prediction_df = prediction_df.withColumn('Cost', F.when(F.col('Cost') < 0, F.lit(0)).otherwise(F.col('Cost')))

    # Update the latest cost dataframe to the current prediction - as this will be used as the latest cost in the next iteration
    latest_cost_df = prediction_df.alias(f'prediction_copy_{current_date}') \
        .select('CostJoinKey', 'Cost', 'CostDiff') \
        .withColumnRenamed('Cost', 'PrevCost')

    # Concatenate the prediction result into a single dataframe
    result = result.union(prediction_df)

# Reduce volume of resulting data frame by removing zero-value rows
result = result.where(F.col('Cost') > 0)
result = result.select('Date', *cost_columns, 'Cost', 'Year', 'Month')

# Write predicted cost to file
target_path = f"abfss://usage@{storageAccount}.dfs.core.windows.net/forecasts/granular-cost-{LOOKBACK_PERIOD}-month-lookback"
result.write.format('parquet').mode('overwrite').partitionBy('Year','Month').option('overwriteSchema', 'true').save(target_path)

import pyspark.sql.functions as F
import pyspark.sql.types as T
import pyspark.sql.window as W
import statsmodels.api as sm
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from datetime import datetime, timedelta
import time

import warnings
warnings.filterwarnings("ignore", category=FutureWarning)

# Integers represent number of months
PREDICTION_END_DATE = '2029-04-01'
LOOKBACK = 6

today = datetime.today().replace(day=1)

prediction_end_date = datetime.strptime(PREDICTION_END_DATE, '%Y-%m-%d')
prediction_interval = (prediction_end_date.year - today.year) * 12 + (prediction_end_date.month - today.month)

lookback_date = (today - timedelta(days=LOOKBACK*30)).replace(day=1)
lookback_date_formatted = lookback_date.strftime('%Y-%m-%d')
lookback_diff = (today.year - lookback_date.year) * 12 + (today.month - lookback_date.month)

# Select appropriate columns
cost_df = cost_df.select('Date', 'CostInBillingCurrency', 'MeterCategory')
cost_df = cost_df.withColumn('Date', F.date_trunc('month', 'Date'))
cost_df = cost_df.groupBy('Date', 'MeterCategory').agg(F.sum('CostInBillingCurrency').alias('Cost')).orderBy('Date')

# Filter away latest month - as we predict cost per month, it will mess up future predictions
cost_df = cost_df.filter(F.col('Date') < F.concat(F.date_format(F.current_date(), 'yyyy'), F.lit('-'), F.date_format(F.current_date(), 'MM'), F.lit('-'), F.lit('01')))

# Create window for iterating over meter categories
window = W.Window.partitionBy("MeterCategory")

# Only look at data within the lookback period
count_df = cost_df.where((F.col('Cost') > 0) & (F.col('Date') >= lookback_date_formatted))

# Calculate the number of month between cost date and today
count_df = count_df.withColumn('months_from_today', F.months_between(F.lit(today), 'Date'))

# Find the lowest month difference across each meter category
count_df = count_df.withColumn('min_month_diff', F.min('months_from_today').over(window))

# Keep meter categories where lowest diff is 1 month - this means it has cost last month - candidate for forecasting
count_df = count_df.withColumn('keep_service', F.when(F.col('min_month_diff') == 1, True).otherwise(False))

# Remove duplicates and prepare for join operation
count_df = count_df.select('MeterCategory', 'keep_service').dropDuplicates(subset=["MeterCategory", "keep_service"])

# # Counting the meter category groups to check if categories have cost in entire time period
# count_df = cost_df.filter((F.col('Cost') > 0) & (F.col('Date') >= lookback_date_formatted)).groupBy("MeterCategory").count()

# # Only keeping meter categories with cost in every month
# cost_df = cost_df.join(count_df, "MeterCategory").filter(count_df["count"] == lookback_diff).drop('count')

# Create schema for resulting df
schema = T.StructType([
    T.StructField("Date", T.TimestampType(), True),
    T.StructField("Cost", T.DoubleType(), True),
    T.StructField("MeterCategory", T.StringType(), True)
])

df = spark.createDataFrame([], schema)

for meter_category in distinct_meter_categories:
    print(f'Processing {meter_category} cost')
    start_time = time.time()
    temp_df = cost_df.where(F.col('MeterCategory') == meter_category).orderBy(F.asc('Date')).select('Date', 'Cost', 'MeterCategory')

    # Convert pyspark df to pandas for OLS model
    temp_pdf = temp_df.toPandas()
    temp_pdf.set_index("Date", inplace=True)

    temp_pdf['x'] = range(len(temp_pdf))

    # Estimate OLS model
    if LOOKBACK > len(temp_pdf['Cost']):
        y = temp_pdf['Cost'].values
        x = temp_pdf['x'].values
    else:
        y = temp_pdf['Cost'].tail(LOOKBACK)
        x = temp_pdf['x'].tail(LOOKBACK)
        
    model = sm.OLS(y, sm.add_constant(x))
    result = model.fit()

    # Configure prediction period
    future_months = pd.date_range(start=temp_pdf.index[-1], periods=prediction_interval, freq="MS")[1:]
    future_x = np.arange(temp_pdf['x'][-1] + 1, temp_pdf['x'][-1] + prediction_interval)

    # Predict future cost
    x = sm.add_constant(future_x)
    predicted_cost = result.predict(x)

    predicted_df = pd.DataFrame({"Date": future_months, "Cost": predicted_cost})
    predicted_df = spark.createDataFrame(predicted_df).withColumn('MeterCategory', F.lit(meter_category))
    updated_df = temp_df.union(predicted_df)
    df = df.union(updated_df)
    end_time = time.time()
    print(f'Successfully processed {meter_category} cost in {round(end_time - start_time, 2)} seconds.')

service_df = service_df.groupBy('service_ResourceType','ServiceName','ServiceCategory', 'ServiceModel').count().drop('count')

# Count number of distinct resourcetypes in dataset
count_df = service_df.groupBy('service_ResourceType').count()

# Separate services with unique resource types (unambiguous in terms of service type) - i.e where the count of resource types is 1

# Merge joined columns with previously merged service columns

cost_df = cost_df.withColumn('ServiceCategory', F.when(F.col('ServiceCategory').isNotNull(), F.col('ServiceCategory')).otherwise(F.col('ambig_ServiceCategory')))
cost_df = cost_df.drop('ambig_ServiceModel', 'ambig_ServiceName', 'ambig_ServiceCategory')

import pandas as pd 
from pyspark.sql import SparkSession
import pyspark.sql.functions as F
# According to the feedback from BPA team (Daniel Lee), we have to filter out all those records that have "Ignored" in OperationalStatus field.

# Transform string fields into integer format, and if there are empty entries, set them to 0
df = df.withColumn('AppID', F.col('AppID').cast("int")).fillna(0, subset=['AppID'])
df = df.withColumn('IsOmniaSubscription', F.col('IsOmniaSubscription').cast("int")).fillna(0, subset=['IsOmniaSubscription'])
df = df.withColumn('BSONo', F.col('BSONo').cast("int")).fillna(0, subset=['BSONo'])
df = df.withColumn('OperationalUnitManagerNo', F.col('OperationalUnitManagerNo').cast("int")).fillna(0, subset=['OperationalUnitManagerNo'])

# Transform string fields into date format
df = df.withColumn('Created', F.to_timestamp('Created'))
df = df.withColumn('Updated', F.to_timestamp('Updated'))
df = df.withColumn('EndOfLifeDate', F.to_timestamp('EndOfLifeDate'))

# Mitigate email part from shortname string such that only employee initials remains
df = df.withColumn("BSOUserName", F.split(df["BSOShortName"], "@").getItem(0))
df = df.withColumn("OperationalManagerUserName", F.split(df["OperationalManagerShortName"], "@").getItem(0))

# Split org unit string into three substrings
split_col = F.split(F.col('OperationalUnitOrgUnit'), " ")
df = df.withColumn("OrgUnitLevel0", split_col.getItem(0))
df = df.withColumn("OrgUnitLevel1", F.concat(split_col.getItem(0), F.lit(" "), split_col.getItem(1)))
df = df.withColumn("OrgUnitLevel2", F.concat(split_col.getItem(0), F.lit(" "), split_col.getItem(1), F.lit(" "), split_col.getItem(2)))

# Define optimized path to save the data
optimized_path = f"abfss://usage@{storageAccount}.dfs.core.windows.net/applications/processed.parquet"

#Save the data with partitioned by time
df.write.format('parquet').mode('overwrite').option('overwriteSchema', 'true').save(optimized_path)

import pyspark.sql.functions as F
import calendar
import datetime

def get_today_formatted():
    today = datetime.date.today()
    formattedDate = f"{today.year}-{str(today.month).zfill(2)}-{str(today.day).zfill(2)}"
    return formattedDate

def is_last_day_of_month():
    today = datetime.date.today()
    last_day_of_month = calendar.monthrange(today.year, today.month)[1]
    return today.day == last_day_of_month

subscription_df = subscription_df.withColumn("BSOUserName", F.split(subscription_df["BSOEmail"], "@").getItem(0))
subscription_df = subscription_df.withColumn("TechnicalOwnerUserName", F.split(subscription_df["TechnicalOwnerEmail"], "@").getItem(0))
subscription_df = subscription_df.drop("BSOEmail", "TechnicalOwnerEmail")

# Store snapshot of subscriptions if last day of month
if (is_last_day_of_month()):
    formattedDate = get_today_formatted()
    target_path = f"abfss://usage@{storageAccount}.dfs.core.windows.net/subscriptions/servicenow/{formattedDate}-optimized.parquet"
    subscription_df.write.format('parquet').mode('overwrite').option('overwriteSchema', 'true').save(target_path)

from datetime import timedelta, datetime
import pytz
from dateutil.relativedelta import relativedelta
import calendar
import json
from notebookutils import mssparkutils
from azure.storage.blob import BlobServiceClient
import pyspark.sql.functions as F
import pyspark.sql.window as W
from pyspark.sql import Row

# Constants
HOURS_PER_YEAR = 8760
KEY_VAULT_NAME = 'acm-toolkit-kv'
LINKED_SERVICE_NAME = 'ACM_Toolkit_kv'
hubAutomationConnectionString = mssparkutils.credentials.getSecret(KEY_VAULT_NAME , 'hubautomation-sa-connectionstring', LINKED_SERVICE_NAME)

blob_service_client = BlobServiceClient.from_connection_string(hubAutomationConnectionString)

# get a reference to the blob container and file of the SQL HUB configuration
container_name = 'sql-config'
blob_name = 'config.json'
container_client = blob_service_client.get_container_client(container_name)
blob_client = container_client.get_blob_client(blob_name)

# download the blob content as a string
blob_content = blob_client.download_blob().content_as_text()

# parse the JSON string into a Python dictionary
sql_config = json.loads(blob_content)

# Compute the variable determining if results should be written to file
day_name = today.strftime("%A")
should_run = sql_config['runDays'][day_name]

sql_metersubcategory_array = sql_config['MeterSubCategory']
sql_days_back_from = sql_config['daysBackFrom']
sql_days_back_to = sql_config['daysBackTo']
sql_enterprise_licence_cores = sql_config['enterprise_licence_cores']
sql_standard_licence_cores = sql_config['enterprise_licence_cores']
yearly_license_cost = sql_config['lic_cost_yearly']

sql_normalized_licence_cores = (4 * sql_enterprise_licence_cores) + sql_standard_licence_cores

# Hourly cost of license per vCPU
hourly_vcpu_cost = yearly_license_cost / (HOURS_PER_YEAR * sql_normalized_licence_cores)

# Only select usage from the period specified in the configuration file
sql_start_date = (datetime.now() - timedelta(days=sql_days_back_from)).strftime('%Y-%m-%d')
sql_end_date = (datetime.now() - timedelta(days=sql_days_back_to)).strftime('%Y-%m-%d')
cost_df = cost_df.where((F.col('Date') >= sql_start_date) & (F.col('Date') <= sql_end_date))

cost_df = cost_df.select(*sql_columns)
cost_df = cost_df.where(F.col('MeterSubCategory').isin(sql_metersubcategory_array))
cost_df = cost_df.where(~F.upper(F.col('ResourceName')).startswith('CVD-'))

# Define SQL type
is_sql_db = (F.col('ResourceId').like('%Microsoft.Sql/servers%')) & (F.col('MeterCategory').like('SQL%'))
is_sql_mi = (F.col('ResourceId').like('%Microsoft.Sql/managedInstances%')) & (F.col('MeterCategory').like('SQL%'))
is_sql_vm = (F.col('MeterCategory') == 'Virtual Machines Licenses') & (F.col('MeterSubCategory').like('SQL Server%'))
is_sql_arc = (F.col('ResourceId').like('%Microsoft.AzureArcData/sqlServerInstances%')) & (F.col('ai_AHB').isNotNull())

# IMPORTANT: Currently ADF cannot be reconfigured without stopping/starting the integration runtime - avoid classifying these instances 
# is_sql_adf = (F.col('MeterCategory') == 'Azure Data Factory v2') & (F.col('MeterSubCategory').like('SSIS%'))

cost_df = cost_df.withColumn('SQLType', 
    F.when(is_sql_db, 'DB')
    .when(is_sql_mi, 'MI')
    .when(is_sql_vm, 'VM')
    .when(is_sql_arc, 'ARC')
    # .when(is_sql_adf, 'ADF')
    .otherwise(None)
)

cost_df = cost_df.where(F.col('SQLType').isNotNull())

# Create new date column
cost_df = cost_df.withColumn('Date', F.current_date())

# Copy df for disabled list computation
cost_copy_df = cost_df.alias('cost_copy_df')
## Compute set of SQL instances getting HUB enabled

# Max aggregation on vCores are used to mitigate duplicate instances, as they can occur if # of vCores are altered on a given day
sql_enable_df = cost_df \
    .select('Date', 'SQLType', 'ResourceId', 'SubscriptionId', 'ResourceGroup', 'ResourceName', 'Quantity', 'ai_VCPUs', 'ai_vCores', 'SQLAHB_VCPUs','LicensePayGUnitPrice') \
    .groupBy('Date', 'SQLType', 'ResourceId', 'SubscriptionId', 'ResourceGroup', 'ResourceName', 'ai_VCPUs', 'LicensePayGUnitPrice') \
    .agg(F.sum('Quantity').alias('ResourceHours'), F.max('ai_vCores').alias('vCores'), F.max('SQLAHB_VCPUs').alias('SQLAHB_VCPUs'))

sql_enable_df = sql_enable_df.withColumn('PAYGLicenseCost', F.col('ResourceHours') * F.col('LicensePayGUnitPrice'))

# Compute hourly HUB license cost 
sql_enable_df = sql_enable_df.withColumn('HUBLicenseCost', F.col('ResourceHours') * F.col('SQLAHB_VCPUs') * hourly_vcpu_cost)

# Compute savings per VCPU
sql_enable_df = sql_enable_df.withColumn('HUBSavingsPerVCPU', (F.col('PAYGLicenseCost') - F.col('HUBLicenseCost')) / F.col('SQLAHB_VCPUs'))

# Sort resources according to which we want to enable HUB for first
sql_enable_df = sql_enable_df.orderBy(F.desc('HUBSavingsPerVCPU'))

window = W.Window.rowsBetween(W.Window.unboundedPreceding, 0)
sql_enable_df = sql_enable_df.withColumn("TotalNormalizedCores", F.sum("SQLAHB_VCPUs").over(window))

# Only include instances that doesnt overshoot the number of available license cores
sql_enable_df = sql_enable_df.where(F.col('TotalNormalizedCores') <= sql_normalized_licence_cores)

# Persist copy for activity log computation
enable_copy_df = sql_enable_df.alias('enable_copy_df')

# Remove redundant columns from results
sql_enable_df = sql_enable_df.select('Date', 'ResourceId', 'SubscriptionId', 'ResourceName', 'ResourceGroup', 'SQLAHB_VCPUs')
## Compute set of SQL instances getting HUB disabled

# Compute list of disabled instances by removing references from the enabled liste
sql_disable_df = cost_copy_df.where(F.col('SQLAHB') == 'Enabled')
sql_disable_df = sql_disable_df.select('Date', 'ResourceId', 'SubscriptionId', 'ResourceName', 'ResourceGroup', 'SQLAHB_VCPUs')
sql_disable_df = sql_disable_df.dropDuplicates(["ResourceId"])
sql_disable_df = sql_disable_df.join(sql_enable_df, 'ResourceId', 'left_anti')
## Store HUB deployment results and update activity log

def compute_activity_log_entry(activity_path):
    csv_options = {'header' : True,
                'delimiter' : ',',
                'quote' : '"',
                'escape' : '"'}
    activity_df = spark.read.options(**csv_options).csv(activity_path)

    # Compute the number of cores ACTUALLY assigned
    sql_assigned_cores = enable_copy_df.agg(F.max('TotalNormalizedCores')).collect()[0][0]

    # Aggregate normalized core per SQL type 
    normalized_cores_by_type = enable_copy_df.select('SQLAHB_VCPUs', 'SQLType').groupBy('SQLType').agg(F.sum('SQLAHB_VCPUs').alias('TotalCores'))

    # Extract aggregate core value per SQL type
    transform_cores = lambda row: 0 if row == None else row[0]
    db_cores = transform_cores(normalized_cores_by_type.where(F.col('SQLType') == 'DB').select('TotalCores').first())
    mi_cores = transform_cores(normalized_cores_by_type.where(F.col('SQLType') == 'MI').select('TotalCores').first())
    vm_cores = transform_cores(normalized_cores_by_type.where(F.col('SQLType') == 'VM').select('TotalCores').first())
    adf_cores = transform_cores(normalized_cores_by_type.where(F.col('SQLType') == 'ADF').select('TotalCores').first())
    arc_cores = transform_cores(normalized_cores_by_type.where(F.col('SQLType') == 'ARC').select('TotalCores').first())

    today_formatted = (today.strftime('%Y-%m-%d'))
    new_activity_row = spark.createDataFrame([(today_formatted, mi_cores, db_cores, vm_cores, adf_cores, arc_cores, sql_normalized_licence_cores, sql_assigned_cores)], activity_df.columns)
    activity_df = activity_df.union(new_activity_row)

    return activity_df

enable_path = 'abfss://sql-hub-logs-v2@hubautomation.dfs.core.windows.net/LATEST-AHUB-Deployment.csv'
disable_path = 'abfss://sql-hub-logs-v2@hubautomation.dfs.core.windows.net/LATEST-AHUB-Removal.csv'
activity_path = 'abfss://sql-activity-v2@hubautomation.dfs.core.windows.net/activity.csv'

print(f"Should run? {should_run}")

if should_run:
    # Store enabled list in storage account
    print("Writing enabled list to SQL latest path")
    sql_enable_df.toPandas().to_csv(enable_path, index=False)

    print("Writing disabled list to SQL latest path")
    # Store disabled list in storage account
    sql_disable_df.toPandas().to_csv(disable_path, index=False)

    # Compute activity log entry and write back to file
    print("Updating SQL activity log")
    activity_df = compute_activity_log_entry(activity_path)
    activity_df.toPandas().to_csv(activity_path, index=False)
# Output 'should_run' indication when running in pipeline

test_path = f'abfss://win-hub-logs@hubautomation.dfs.core.windows.net/{deploy_date}-AHUB-Deployment.csv'
csv_options = {'header' : True,
                'delimiter' : ';',
                'quote' : '"',
                'escape' : '"'}
add_df = spark.read.options(**csv_options).csv(test_path)

add_ids = [row[0] for row in add_df.select("ResourceId").collect()]

test_path = f'abfss://win-hub-logs@hubautomation.dfs.core.windows.net/{deploy_date}-AHUB-Removal.csv'
csv_options = {'header' : True,
                'delimiter' : ';',
                'quote' : '"',
                'escape' : '"'}
rm_df = spark.read.options(**csv_options).csv(test_path)

rm_ids = [row[0] for row in rm_df.select("ResourceId").collect()]

cost_path = monthly_path = f'abfss://usage@{storageAccount}.dfs.core.windows.net/exports/monthly/ACMMonthlyActualCost/{start_of_month.replace("-", "")}-{end_of_month.replace("-", "")}/Extended_v3_ACMMonthlyActualCost_{start_of_month.replace("-", "")}-{end_of_month.replace("-", "")}.parquet'
test_cost = spark.read.format('parquet').load(cost_path)

cost_pre = test_cost.where(F.col('Date') == pre_date)
cost_pre_ne = cost_pre.where(F.col('WindowsAHB') == 'Not Enabled').dropDuplicates(['ResourceId'])
cost_pre = cost_pre.where(F.col('WindowsAHB') == 'Enabled').dropDuplicates(['ResourceId'])

cost_today = test_cost.where(F.col('Date') >= start_of_month)
cost_today_ne = cost_today.where(F.col('WindowsAHB') == 'Not Enabled').dropDuplicates(['ResourceId'])
cost_today = cost_today.where(F.col('WindowsAHB') == 'Enabled').dropDuplicates(['ResourceId'])

cost_post = test_cost.where(F.col('Date') == post_date)
cost_post_ne = cost_post.where(F.col('WindowsAHB') == 'Not Enabled').dropDuplicates(['ResourceId'])
cost_post = cost_post.where(F.col('WindowsAHB') == 'Enabled').dropDuplicates(['ResourceId'])

pre_ids = [row[0] for row in cost_pre.select("ResourceId").collect()]
post_ids = [row[0] for row in cost_post.select("ResourceId").collect()]

pre = set(pre_ids)
post = set(post_ids)
added = set(add_ids)
removed = set(rm_ids)

kept = pre.intersection(post)
diff = added.intersection(pre)

add_w_vcpu = add_df.join(cost_today, 'ResourceId', 'left')
rm_w_vcpu = rm_df.join(cost_today, 'ResourceId', 'left')

#### Calculate over/under assignment of HUB
1. Compute # of resources with HUB and # of VCPUs on 12th of March (pre) **318** (2025)
2. Compute # of resources with HUB and # of VCPUs on 14th of March (post) **294** (2689)
3. Compute # of resources with HUB enabled and # of VCPUs on 13th of March (added) **313** (1341)

- **11** of these resources does not exist any longer, and deployment fails for these. These account for **80** normalized cores

4. Compute # of resources with HUB disabled and # of VCPUs on 13th of March (removed) **50** (528)
5. How many resources/vCPUs was included kept from 12th to 14th (kept)? **243** (1289)

- **9** of the resources marked as _HUB Enabled_ is not reflected in the normalized core column. These are **Azure Arc-Enabled SQL Server** instances and amount to **184** normalized cores (but are not reflected in the extend files)
 
6. How many resources/vCPUs was similar on the 12th and the enabled list? (1199)
7. How many resources/vCPUs was similar on the 14th and the enabled list?
8. How many resources in the disabled list was enabled on the 12th? (should be all)
9. How many resources in the disabled list was enabled on the 14th? (should be none)
10. How many resources on the enable list was not enabled on the 14th?
11. How many enabled resources on the 14th was not in the enable list?
12. How many resources was failed to enabled/diabled on the 13th?


- Are more/less normalized cores being enabled than available licenses?
- Get list of resources not being enabled that should be enabled
- Get list of resources that are enabled but are not in the enabled list
- Do the same for Windows HUB

### SUMMARY

HOW MANY RESOURCES ON 12th

HOW MANY ENABLED ON 13th

HOW MANY RESOURCE ON 14th

HOW MANY RESOURCES ON 12th NOT IN ENABLED LIST

HOW MANY RESOURCES ON 14th NOT IN ENABLED LIST

pre_count = cost_pre.count()
pre_cores = cost_pre.agg(F.sum('WindowsAHB_VCPUS')).collect()[0][0]
post_count = cost_post.count()
post_cores = cost_post.agg(F.sum('WindowsAHB_VCPUS')).collect()[0][0]

added_count = add_w_vcpu.count()
added_cores = add_w_vcpu.agg(F.sum('WindowsAHB_VCPUS')).collect()[0][0]
added_not_exists_count = add_w_vcpu.where(F.col('WindowsAHB').isNull()).count() or 0
added_not_exists_cores = add_w_vcpu.where(F.col('WindowsAHB').isNull()).agg(F.sum('ai_VCPUs')).collect()[0][0] or 0 # Not normalized

print(f"Number of resources with HUB on date before deployment {pre_date}: {pre_count} ({pre_cores} normalized cores)")
print(f"Number of resources in HUB deployment on {deploy_date}: {added_count} ({added_cores} normalized cores)")
print(f"Number of resource with HUB on date after deployment {post_date}: {post_count} ({post_cores} normalized cores)")
print(' ')
print(f"Expected number of HUB resources on {post_date}: {added_count} ({added_cores} normalized cores)")
print(f"Actual number of HUB resources on {post_date}: {post_count} ({post_cores} normalized cores)")
print(' ')
print(f"Number of resources scheduled for HUB deployment that doesn't exist per {deploy_date}: {added_not_exists_count} ({added_not_exists_cores} NOT normalized cores)")
print(f"The new expected number of HUB resources on {post_date}: {added_count - added_not_exists_count} ({added_cores - added_not_exists_cores} NOT normalized cores)")
print(' ')
print(f"Out of the {pre_count} HUB resources day before deployment, {rm_count} were scheduled for removal ({rm_cores} normalized cores)")
print(f"Out of the {rm_count} HUB resources scheduled for removal on {deploy_date}, {pre_removed_count} ({pre_removed_cores} normalized cores) resources had HUB deployed on {pre_date}")
print('')
print(f"Out of the {pre_count} HUB resources from {pre_date}, {kept_count} ({kept_cores} normalized cores) of the same resources still had HUB applied {post_date}")
print(f"Out of the {pre_count} HUB resources from {pre_date}, {pre_added_count} ({pre_added_cores} normalized cores) of the same resources were in the deploy list on {deploy_date}")
print(f"Out of the {post_count} HUB resources from {post_date}, {post_added_count} ({post_added_cores} normalized cores) of the same resources were in the deploy list on {deploy_date}")
print(' ')
print(f"{post_added_ne_count} ({post_added_ne_cores} normalized cores) resources that were scheduled for deployment on {deploy_date}, did not have HUB enabled on {post_date}")
print(' ')
print(f"Out of the {post_count} HUB resources on {post_date}, there are {post_not_in_added_count} ({post_not_in_added_cores} normalized cores) that are not referenced on the deployment list on {deploy_date}")
print(f"Out of the {pre_count} HUB resources on {pre_date}, there are {pre_not_in_added_count} ({pre_not_in_added_cores} normalized cores) that are not referenced on the deployment list on {deploy_date}")
print(" ")

expected_count = added_count
expected_cores = added_cores
print(f"Having {expected_count} ({expected_cores} normalized cores) resources scheduled for deployment, but there are {post_count} ({post_cores} normalized cores) HUB resources day after deployment")

expected_count -= added_not_exists_count
expected_cores -= added_not_exists_cores
print(f"Subtracting the scheduled resources that doesent exist {added_not_exists_count} ({added_not_exists_cores} NOT normalized cores), we can expect {expected_count} ({expected_cores} normalized cores) resources for deployment")

expected_post_count = post_not_in_added_count + expected_count
expected_post_cores = post_not_in_added_cores + expected_cores
print(f"Taking into account the resources with HUB post deployment that weren't referenced in HUB schedule {post_not_in_added_count} ({post_not_in_added_cores} normalized cores), the expected number of HUB resources day after deployment should be {expected_post_count} ({expected_post_cores} normalized cores)")

expected_diff_count = expected_post_count - post_count 
expected_diff_cores = expected_post_cores - post_cores
print(f"Conclusion: there are being deployed {expected_diff_count} ({expected_diff_cores} normalized cores) less HUB resources than expected")

This notebook creates a dataset of employee ID, shortname, Business Area and sub-Business Area (e.g. BA: PDP, subBA: PDP PSR). The BA and subBA is found from the employee's manager at level 2 and 3. The employee hierarchy has been made in another notebook (usersWithManagerSnapshot_v1). Both notebooks use the same inital raw-dataset from ADLS from graphAPI (AzureADUsersWithManager_).

container = 'usage'
file_path = 'abfss://' + container + '@' + storageAccount + '.dfs.core.windows.net/' + 'AzureAD_BusinessAreaLevel/bronze/AzureAD_EmployeesManagersSnapshot.parquet'

df_users = spark.read.format('parquet').load(file_path).toPandas()
# df_users.head(10)

# Get Hierarchy-dataframe from ADLS
file_path = 'abfss://' + container + '@' + storageAccount + '.dfs.core.windows.net/' + 'AzureAD_BusinessAreaLevel/silver/usersWithManagerSnapshot_v1.parquet'

employees = spark.read.format('parquet').load(file_path).toPandas()
# employees.head(10)

print(f"Old length of the dataset is: {df_users.shape[0]}")

# Filter out disabled accounts
df_users = df_users[df_users.accountEnabled == True]

# Drop rows with no employee ID
df_users = df_users.dropna(subset=['employeeId'])

print(f"New length of the dataset is: {df_users.shape[0]}")

## Split email and filter out equinor-domain
cannot call on NoneType, need to rename first:
df_users = df_users.fillna({'department': 'missing'})

# Getting the username by splitting e-mail name before "@"-symbol
df_users['userName'] = [email[:email.find('@')] for email in df_users['userPrincipalName']]

# Getting the domain name by splitting e-mail after "@"-symbol
df_users['domain'] = [email[email.find('@'):] for email in df_users['userPrincipalName']]

print(f"Old length of the dataset is: {df_users.shape[0]}")

# Only include empoyees who has a email address with domain-name equinor.com
df_users = df_users[df_users.domain == '@equinor.com']

# Delete non-valid employeeIDs
df_users = df_users[df_users['employeeId'] != 'FunctionKey']

print(f"New length of the dataset is: {df_users.shape[0]}")

# First isolate all duplicates that we want to remove. In this instance there is one duplicate that contains employee information, and another that does not.
# All duplicates without information will be isolated in a variable and removed from the dataset

# Where employeeId don't occur more than once 
mask1 = df_users['employeeId'].isin(df_users.employeeId.value_counts().loc[lambda x: x>1].index)

# Where users have empty values in the columns specified
mask2 = df_users['department'].isna()
mask3 = df_users['manager_employeeId'].isna()
mask4 = df_users['manager_displayName'].isna()
mask5 = df_users['manager_userPrincipalName'].isna()
mask6 = df_users['manager_department'].isna()

# Where the username contains sub-string 'ja_'
mask7 = df_users['userName'].str.contains('ja_')

duplicates = df_users[mask1 & mask2 & mask3 & mask4 & mask5 | mask6 & mask7]

df_users = df_users.drop(duplicates.index)
# some users are registrered with two different employeeId and corresponding department, manager etc. but the same displayName
## Merge Hierarchy-dataframe from ADLS-opt to raw-data
Only looking at employeeID - managerID and find all corresponding departments (business area)

# merge employeeId+department to the user hierarchy for employee and manager 2, 3, 4
employees = employees.merge(df_users[['employeeId', 'department']],
                            left_on='employeeId_0',
                            right_on='employeeId',
                            how='left').drop(columns={'employeeId'}).rename(columns={'department':'departmentEmployee'})

employees = employees.merge(df_users[['employeeId', 'department']],
                            left_on='Manager2',
                            right_on='employeeId',
                            how='left').drop(columns={'employeeId'}).rename(columns={'department':'departmentManager2'})

employees = employees.merge(df_users[['employeeId', 'department']],
                            left_on='Manager3', 
                            right_on='employeeId',
                            how='left').drop(columns={'employeeId'}).rename(columns={'department':'departmentManager3'})

employees = employees.merge(df_users[['employeeId', 'department']],
                            left_on='Manager4',
                            right_on='employeeId',
                            how='left').drop(columns={'employeeId'}).rename(columns={'department':'departmentManager4'})

# Due to poor data quality, multiple employeers will have the wrong Manager1 for two reasons:
# employeeId has itself listed as manager OR two employees have each other listed as managers
# in these cases Manager1 has been sat to '0'
# Rename these instances to "No data"
employees['departmentManager2'] = employees.apply(lambda x: 'No data' if x['Manager1'] =='0' else x['departmentManager2'], axis=1)
employees['departmentManager3'] = employees.apply(lambda x: 'No data' if x['Manager1'] =='0' else x['departmentManager3'], axis=1)
employees['departmentManager4'] = employees.apply(lambda x: 'No data' if x['Manager1'] =='0' else x['departmentManager4'], axis=1)
# # Azure AD users with no information about their department/business area due to data quality

# # Count number of employees under each Business Area (on Manager level 2)
# df_grouped= employees.groupby(['departmentManager2'])['departmentManager2'].count()
# df_grouped_sorted = df_grouped.sort_values()
# print(df_grouped_sorted)
## Set Business Area, Business Area Level 1 and Business Area Level 2
# Set BusinessArea equal to each employees level 2 managers department
# Set BusinessArea Level 1 equal to each employees level 3 managers department
# Set BusinessArea Level 2 equal to each employees level 4 managers department
Save for later just in case

# # Set BusinessArea for FLX
# employees['businessArea']= employees.apply(lambda x: x['departmentManager3'] if x['departmentManager3'] =='FLX' else x['businessArea'], axis=1)

# # Set subBusinessArea for FLX
# employees['subBusinessArea']= employees.apply(lambda x: x['departmentManager4'] if x['businessArea'] =='FLX' else x['subBusinessArea'], axis=1)

# # Set BusinessArea for "CFO FCoE"
# employees['businessArea']= employees.apply(lambda x: 'CFO FCOE' if ('CFO FCOE' in str(x['departmentManager3'])) else x['businessArea'], axis=1)

# # Set subBusinessArea for "CFO FCoE"
# employees['subBusinessArea']= employees.apply(lambda x: x['departmentManager4'] if ('CFO FCOE' in str(x['businessArea'])) else x['subBusinessArea'], axis=1)

# # Set BusinessArea for "PDP DW"
# employees['BusinessArea']= employees.apply(lambda x: 'PDP DW' if ('PDP DW' in str(x['Manager3_department'])) else x['BusinessArea'], axis=1)

# # Set BusinessArea for "PDP PSR"
# employees['BusinessArea']= employees.apply(lambda x: 'PDP PSR' if ('PDP PSR' in str(x['Manager3_department'])) else x['BusinessArea'], axis=1)

# # Set BusinessArea for "PDP PRD"
# employees['BusinessArea']= employees.apply(lambda x: 'PDP PRD' if ('PDP PRD' in str(x['Manager3_department'])) else x['BusinessArea'], axis=1)

# add username/shortname to dataframe
employees = employees.merge(df_users[['employeeId', 'userName', 'userPrincipalName']],
                            left_on='employeeId_0',
                            right_on='employeeId',
                            how='left')

# only keep relevant columns
employees_short = employees[['employeeId',
                             'userName',
                             'userPrincipalName',
                             'businessArea',
                             'businessAreaLevel1',
                             'businessAreaLevel2']].copy()

employees_short = employees_short.rename(columns={'userPrincipalName' : 'email'})

employees_short['email'] = employees_short['email'].str.lower()
employees_short['userName'] = employees_short['userName'].str.upper()

print(f" Duplicated usernames: {len(employees_short['userName'].value_counts().loc[lambda x: x>1])}")

print(f" Duplicated employee IDs: {len(employees_short['employeeId'].value_counts().loc[lambda x: x>1])}")

print(f" Duplicated e-mails: {len(employees_short['email'].value_counts().loc[lambda x: x>1])}")

#Set optimized path
optimized_path = file_path = 'abfss://' + container + '@' + storageAccount + '.dfs.core.windows.net/' + 'AzureAD_BusinessAreaLevel/gold/usersWithBusinessAreaSnapshot_v1.parquet'

df_spark = spark.createDataFrame(employees_short)

df_spark.write.format('parquet').mode('overwrite').save(optimized_path)
#df_spark.write.format('parquet').mode('overwrite').option('overwriteSchema', 'True').save(optimized_path)

file_path = 'abfss://' + container + '@' + storageAccount + '.dfs.core.windows.net/AzureAD_BusinessAreaLevel/bronze/AzureAD_EmployeesManagersSnapshot.parquet'

# Read in the dataframe using Spark and transform it into a Pandas-core DataFrame
df_users = spark.read.format('parquet').load(file_path).toPandas()
# df_users.head(10)

print(f"Old length of the dataset is: {df_users.shape[0]}")

# Filter out disabled accounts
df_users = df_users[df_users.accountEnabled == True]

# Drop rows with no employee ID
df_users = df_users.dropna(subset=['employeeId'])

print(f"New length of the dataset is: {df_users.shape[0]}")

#### Split email and filter out Equinor-domain
cannot call on NoneType, need to rename first: 
df_users = df_users.fillna({'department': 'missing'})

# Getting the username by splitting e-mail name before "@"-symbol
df_users['userName'] = [email[:email.find('@')] for email in df_users['userPrincipalName']]

# Getting the domain name by splitting e-mail after "@"-symbol
df_users['domain'] = [email[email.find('@'):] for email in df_users['userPrincipalName']]

print(f"Old length of the dataset is: {df_users.shape[0]}")

# Only include empoyees who has a email address with domain-name equinor.com
df_users = df_users[df_users.domain == '@equinor.com']

# Delete non-valid employeeIDs
df_users = df_users[df_users['employeeId'] != 'FunctionKey']

print(f"New length of the dataset is: {df_users.shape[0]}")
# # some users are registrered with two different employeeId and corresponding department, manager etc. but the same displayName

print(f"Old length of the dataset is: {df_users.shape[0]}")

# First isolate all duplicates that we want to remove. In this instance there is one duplicate that contains employee information, and another that does not.
# All duplicates without information will be isolated in a variable and removed from the dataset

duplicates = df_users[(df_users['employeeId'].isin(df_users.employeeId.value_counts().loc[lambda x: x>1].index)) & (df_users['department'].isna()) & (df_users['manager_employeeId'].isna()) & (df_users['manager_displayName'].isna()) & (df_users['manager_userPrincipalName'].isna()) | (df_users['userName'].str.contains('ja_')) & (df_users['manager_department'].isna())]

df_users = df_users.drop(duplicates.index)

print(f"New length of the dataset is: {df_users.shape[0]}")
The hierarchy-table will only connect employeeID to the managerIDs above

# Make df of employeeId and managerId
df_id = df_users[['employeeId', 'manager_employeeId']].copy()

# Store employeeID who has them self as manager
df_id_wrong_format = df_id[df_id['employeeId'] == df_id['manager_employeeId']]

#### Merge df
Create a total df that connect the employeeID to its closest manager. Merge df_id to itself untill only 1 unique employeeID is at the top.


**Note:** there are two possibilities of poor data quality that we need to address since they cause infinate loops or wrong information about level in hierarchy as well as connection to the correct top leader.
1. An employee has itself listed as a manger: employeeId: X, managerId: X
2. Two employees has each other listed as manager: employeeId: X, managerId: Y and employeeId: Y, managerId: X

# Start with copy the first two columns of employeeId and managerId
df_total = df_id.copy()

# Connect the manager to the next manager and drop the duplicate column
df_total = df_total.merge(df_id,
                          left_on='manager_employeeId',
                          right_on='employeeId',
                          how='left',
                          suffixes=['_0','_1'])

df_total = df_total.drop(columns=['employeeId_1'])

# if an employee has itself listed as the manager, replace manager_id to be '0' for tracking and further handling in the future
df_total['manager_employeeId_1'] = df_total.apply(lambda x: '0' \
                                                    if (x['manager_employeeId_1'] == x['manager_employeeId_0']) \
                                                    else x['manager_employeeId_1'], axis=1)
We're now moving up the hierarchy tree to find the managers of each employee. If we haven't hit the top of the tree within hitting the threshold, we can ignore those employees.

# Set a threshold for how far up the tree we want to go.
thres = 10

for n in range(1, thres):
    # Merge the employee with the n-th manager above the employee
    df_total = df_total.merge(df_id, left_on = f'manager_employeeId_{n}', right_on = 'employeeId', how = 'left')
    # Drop the employeeId-column so as not to create duplicated columns
    df_total = df_total.drop(columns = ['employeeId'])
    # Rename the merged manager_employeeId to the next level of manager (n + 1)
    df_total = df_total.rename(columns = {'manager_employeeId' : f'manager_employeeId_{n+1}'})

    #To avoid loops caused by poor data quality:
    #If two employees have each other as their manager, this will cause a never ending loop.
    #This is the case if e.g. manager 3 = manager 1. In this case we set the manager_Id to be 0, so that it can be easily picked up and further handled in the future.
    df_total[f'manager_employeeId_{n+1}'] = df_total.apply(lambda x: '0' \
                                                            if (x[f'manager_employeeId_{n+1}'] == x[f'manager_employeeId_{n}']) \
                                                            or (x[f'manager_employeeId_{n+1}'] == x[f'manager_employeeId_{n-1}']) \
                                                            else x[f'manager_employeeId_{n+1}'], axis=1)

    # Iterate untill only 1 unique person at the top of hierarchy
    if df_total[f'manager_employeeId_{n+1}'].nunique() == 1:
        break
Define a level indicating how many managers is above. E.g. vp has normally 3 managers and will be at level 4

# Count total number of columns in hierarchy and substract number of empty-cells
num_columns = df_total.shape[1]
df_total['level'] = df_total.apply(lambda x: num_columns - x.isnull().sum(), axis='columns')

print(f"Old length of the dataset is: {df_total.shape[0]}")

# Extract employees with no department etc.
df_removeId = df_users[(df_users['department'].isna()) & (df_users['manager_employeeId'].isna()) & (df_users['manager_displayName'].isna()) & (df_users['manager_userPrincipalName'].isna()) & (df_users['manager_department'].isna())]
df_removeId = df_removeId[['employeeId', 'manager_employeeId']]

# Store IDs in df for easy access if needed
df_id_wrong_format = df_id_wrong_format.append(df_removeId)

# Remove from hierarchy-table
df_total = df_total[~df_total['employeeId_0'].isin(df_id_wrong_format['employeeId'])]

print(f"New length of the dataset is: {df_total.shape[0]}")
#### Final steps to hierarchy of employeeID and corresponding Managers for all levels

# List of all levels in decreasing order
level_list = df_total.level.sort_values().unique()

# Empty list to be filled by for-loop
df_list = []

# Create df for each level and store in list df_list
for level in level_list:
    vars()[f'df_level{level}'] = df_total[df_total['level']== level].copy()
    df_list.append(vars()[f'df_level{level}'])

# Tuple of level and corresponding df, i.e. ( (1, df_level1), (2, df_level2), ...)
combined_tuple = list(zip(level_list, df_list))

df_hierarchy = df_list[0].copy()

# Append all df_levels 2-8
for df in df_list[1:]:
    df_hierarchy = df_hierarchy.append(df)

# Remove redundant columns manager_employeeId 0-6
for level in level_list[:-1]:
    df_hierarchy = df_hierarchy.drop(columns = {f'manager_employeeId_{level-1}'})

### Dataframes in the notebook
1. df_hierarchy shows employeeID, level, Manager1, Manager2 etc. NB! Those employees which have Manager1=0 is not correctly linked to the top leader of the company due to poor data quality. They are included so that one can link to a person registrered in Azure AD, but information about level (or business area/department) will not be accurate.
2. df_users All info about employeeID, department, manager, etc
3. df_id_wrong_format employeeID with wrong info: missing info or them self as manager

#Set optimized path

optimized_path = 'abfss://' + container + '@' + storageAccount + '.dfs.core.windows.net/AzureAD_BusinessAreaLevel/silver/usersWithManagerSnapshot_v1.parquet'

df_spark = spark.createDataFrame(df_hierarchy)

df_spark.write.format('parquet').mode('overwrite').save(optimized_path)
# df_spark.write.format('parquet').mode('overwrite').option('overwriteSchema', 'true').save(optimized_path)

properties.description: This notebook aggregates the cost from the csv cost file and compares it to the aggregated cost of the extended parquet cost file.

source:
import pandas as pd 
import pyspark.sql.functions as F
import pyspark.sql.types as T

# Aggregate the entire cost history for both raw and processed data based on cost type ('AmortizedCost' or 'ActualCost')

def aggregate_cost_data(cost_type):
    # Create schema for cost aggregation
    schema = T.StructType([
        T.StructField("Date", T.TimestampType(), True),
        T.StructField("RawDataTotalCost", T.DoubleType(), True),
        T.StructField("ProcessedDataTotalCost", T.DoubleType(), True),
        T.StructField("TotalCostDiff", T.IntegerType(), True),
        T.StructField("CostType", T.StringType(), True)
    ])

    # Create an empty DataFrame with the specified schema
    df = spark.createDataFrame([], schema=schema)

    # Define the root path
    root_path = f"abfss://{container}@{storageAccount}.dfs.core.windows.net/exports/monthly/ACMMonthly{cost_type}"

    # Collect all the folders under this root path
    folders = mssparkutils.fs.ls(root_path)

    for folder in folders:
        # List all file paths in current folder
        files = mssparkutils.fs.ls(root_path +'/'+ str(folder.name))
        file_paths = [file.path for file in files]

        # Find the raw data file (csv) and processed data (extended data file - parquet)
        csv_file = next(filter(lambda file_path: "csv" in file_path, file_paths), None)
        extended_file = next(filter(lambda file_path: "Extended_v2" in file_path, file_paths), None)
        
        try:
            # Extract date for current folder
            date = pd.to_datetime(folder.path.split('/')[-1].split('-')[0],format="%Y/%m/%d")

            # Read raw data and transformed fata
            csv_df = spark.read.format('csv').load(csv_file, header=True)
            extended_df = spark.read.format('parquet').load(extended_file)

            # Aggregate on cost for raw data file
            agg_csv_df = csv_df.select(F.sum(F.col('CostInBillingCurrency')).alias('RawDataTotalCost'))
            agg_csv_df = agg_csv_df.withColumn("Date", F.lit(date).cast(T.TimestampType()))

            # Aggregate on cost for processed data file
            agg_extended_df = extended_df.select(F.sum(F.col('CostInBillingCurrency')).alias('ProcessedDataTotalCost'))
            agg_extended_df = agg_extended_df.withColumn("Date", F.lit(date).cast(T.TimestampType()))

            # Combine aggregated cost data into one dataframe
            combined_df = agg_csv_df.join(agg_extended_df, on="Date", how="left")

            # Compute difference between the raw and processed total cost
            combined_df = combined_df.withColumn("TotalCostDiff", F.expr("FLOOR(ABS(ProcessedDataTotalCost - RawDataTotalCost))"))

            combined_df = combined_df.withColumn("CostType", F.lit(cost_type))

            # Add aggregated cost to historic aggregations
            df = df.union(combined_df)

        except Exception as e:
            print(f"Error processing the {folder.name} folder contents: {e}")

    return df

# Combine aggregated amortized and actual cost into a single dataframe
total_cost_df = actual_cost_df.union(amortized_cost_df)

# Display the total aggregated cost difference of the entire cost data history
# The computed value should always be 0 when historic data has been processed properly
# If the aggregated cost diff is greater than 0, the extend script is erroneous and produces inconsistent data
total_cost_df.select(F.sum(F.col("TotalCostDiff")).alias("AggregatedCostDiff")).show()

from datetime import timedelta, datetime
from dateutil.relativedelta import relativedelta
import calendar
import json
import pytz
from notebookutils import mssparkutils
from azure.storage.blob import BlobServiceClient
import pyspark.sql.functions as F
import pyspark.sql.window as W
from pyspark.sql import Row

# Constants
HOURS_PER_YEAR = 8760
VCPUS_PER_LICENSE = 16
KEY_VAULT_NAME = 'acm-toolkit-kv'
LINKED_SERVICE_NAME = 'ACM_Toolkit_kv'
hubAutomationConnectionString = mssparkutils.credentials.getSecret(KEY_VAULT_NAME , 'hubautomation-sa-connectionstring', LINKED_SERVICE_NAME)

# Name of resource groups containing terminal server (TS) virtual machines
# The TS VMs have a pre-allocated set of HUB licenses, and should be excluded from the calculation in this script
TS_VM_RG = [
    'RG-TERMINAL_SERVERS-NOE',
    'RG-TERMINAL_SERVERS-NOW',
    'RG-TERMINAL_SERVERS-SCUS'

blob_service_client = BlobServiceClient.from_connection_string(hubAutomationConnectionString)

# Get a reference to the blob container and file of the VM HUB configuration
container_name = 'win-config'
blob_name = 'config.json'
container_client = blob_service_client.get_container_client(container_name)
blob_client = container_client.get_blob_client(blob_name)

# Download the blob content as a string
blob_content = blob_client.download_blob().content_as_text()

# Parse downloaded blob as json
vm_config = json.loads(blob_content)

# Compute the variable determining if results should be written to file
day_name = today.strftime("%A")
should_run = vm_config['runDays'][day_name]

license_count = vm_config['lic_count']
ts_vms = vm_config['ts_vms']
timespan = vm_config['timespan']
yearly_license_cost = vm_config['lic_cost_yearly']
available_licenses = license_count - ts_vms

# Hourly cost of license per vCPU
hourly_vcpu_cost = yearly_license_cost / (license_count * HOURS_PER_YEAR * VCPUS_PER_LICENSE)

# Filter usage to timespan defined in configuration file
vm_start_date = (today - timedelta(days=timespan)).strftime('%Y-%m-%d')
cost_df = cost_df.where(F.col('Date') >= vm_start_date)

# Use only VM related cost
is_vm_cost = ((F.col('ResourceId').contains('/virtualMachines/')) | (F.col('ResourceId').contains('/virtualMachineScaleSets/'))) \
    & ((F.col('MeterSubCategory').contains('Windows')) | (F.col('ServiceInfo2').contains('Windows Server BYOL'))) \
    & ((F.col('MeterCategory') == 'Virtual Machines') | (F.col('MeterCategory') == 'Virtual Machines Licenses')) \
    & (F.col('ai_VCPUs').isNotNull())

cost_df = cost_df.where(is_vm_cost).select(*vm_columns)

# Removing the VMs who's ResourceName begins with 'CVD-' as these are Windows Client VM's and not relevant for consideration of a Windows Server licence
cost_df = cost_df.where(~F.upper(F.col('ResourceName')).startswith('CVD-'))

# Create new date column
cost_df = cost_df.withColumn('Date', F.current_date())

# Persist a df copy for disable list calculation
cost_copy_df = cost_df.alias('cost_copy_df')
## Compute set VMs getting HUB Enabled

# Columns used for aggregated result
selected_columns = [
    'Date',
    'ResourceId',
    'SubscriptionId',
    'ResourceGroup',
    'ResourceName',
    'WindowsAHB_VCPUs',
    'ai_VCPUs',
    'LicensePayGUnitPrice'
]

# Scalesets and virtual machines is different in how the licence cost is calculated
# In order to retain the correct number of vCPUs when later grouping by ResourceId the Quantity needs to be divided by the 
# number of nodes in the scaleset before multiplying by vCPUs and price per hour
cost_df = cost_df.withColumn('NodeCount',
    F.when(F.col('ResourceId').contains('/virtualMachineScaleSets/'), 1)
    .otherwise(0)
)

# Aggregate quantities and node counts in order to make HUB savings calculation simpler
cost_df = cost_df \
    .select(*selected_columns, 'NodeCount', 'Quantity') \
    .groupBy(*selected_columns)\
    .agg(F.sum('Quantity').alias('Quantity'), F.sum('NodeCount').alias('NodeCount'))

# Compute hourly PAYG license cost
cost_df = cost_df.withColumn('PAYGLicenseCost', F.col('Quantity') * F.col('LicensePayGUnitPrice'))

# If cost is related to scaleset, the license cost must be divided by the number of nodes
cost_df = cost_df.withColumn('PAYGLicenseCost', F.when(F.col('NodeCount') > 0, F.col('PAYGLicenseCost') / F.col('NodeCount')).otherwise(F.col('PAYGLicenseCost')))

# Compute hourly HUB license cost 
cost_df = cost_df.withColumn('HUBLicenseCost', F.col('Quantity') * F.col('WindowsAHB_VCPUs') * hourly_vcpu_cost)

# If cost is related to scaleset, the license cost must be divided by the number of nodes
cost_df = cost_df.withColumn('HUBLicenseCost', F.when(F.col('NodeCount') > 0, F.col('HUBLicenseCost') / F.col('NodeCount')).otherwise(F.col('HUBLicenseCost')))

# Compute savings per VCPU
cost_df = cost_df.withColumn('HUBSavingsPerVCPU', (F.col('PAYGLicenseCost') - F.col('HUBLicenseCost')) / F.col('WindowsAHB_VCPUs'))

cost_df = cost_df.drop('NodeCount')
cost_df = cost_df.orderBy(F.desc('HUBSavingsPerVCPU'))

# # Exclude terminal server VMs (as their HUB assignment are managed separately)
cost_df = cost_df.where(~F.col('ResourceGroup').isin(TS_VM_RG))

# Compute the cumulative number of normalized VCPUs
window = W.Window.rowsBetween(W.Window.unboundedPreceding, 0)
cost_df = cost_df.withColumn("TotalNormalizedCores", F.sum("WindowsAHB_VCPUs").over(window))

# Only include the highest yielding resources up until the cumulative normalized cores equals the equivalent amount of available licenses
vm_enable_df = cost_df.where(F.col('TotalNormalizedCores') / VCPUS_PER_LICENSE <= available_licenses)

# # Remove redundant columns
vm_enable_df = vm_enable_df.select(*selected_columns)
## Compute set of VMs getting HUB disabled

# Only VMs with HUB enabled are eligible to being disabled
vm_disable_df = cost_copy_df.where(F.col('WindowsAHB') == 'Enabled')

vm_disable_df = vm_disable_df \
    .select(*selected_columns) \
    .groupBy(selected_columns) \
    .count().drop('count')

# Exclude VMs that are already in the list of enabled VMs
vm_disable_df = vm_disable_df.join(vm_enable_df, 'ResourceId', 'left_anti')
## Store HUB deployment results and update activity log

def compute_activity_log_entry(activity_path):
    # Load existing log
    csv_options = {'header' : True,
                    'delimiter' : ',',
                    'quote' : '"',
                    'escape' : '"'}
    activity_df = spark.read.options(**csv_options).csv(activity_path)

    today_formatted = (today.strftime('%Y-%m-%d'))
    disabled_vms_count = vm_disable_df.count()
    enabled_vms_count = vm_enable_df.count()
    normalized_cores_disabled = vm_disable_df.select('WindowsAHB_VCPUs').agg(F.sum('WindowsAHB_VCPUs')).collect()[0][0] or 0
    normalized_cores_enabled = vm_enable_df.select('WindowsAHB_VCPUs').agg(F.sum('WindowsAHB_VCPUs')).collect()[0][0] or 0
    licenses_removed = normalized_cores_disabled / VCPUS_PER_LICENSE
    licenses_applied = normalized_cores_enabled / VCPUS_PER_LICENSE

    row_values = [ 
        disabled_vms_count, 
        enabled_vms_count, 
        normalized_cores_disabled, 
        normalized_cores_enabled, 
        licenses_removed, 
        licenses_applied,
        license_count,
        ts_vms,
        available_licenses
    ]

    new_activity_row = spark.createDataFrame([(today_formatted, *row_values)], activity_df.columns)
    activity_df = activity_df.union(new_activity_row)
    return activity_df

enable_path = f'abfss://win-hub-logs-v2@hubautomation.dfs.core.windows.net/LATEST-AHUB-Deployment.csv'
disable_path = f'abfss://win-hub-logs-v2@hubautomation.dfs.core.windows.net/LATEST-AHUB-Removal.csv'

print(f"Should run? {should_run}")

# Only persist result according to storage account configuration
if should_run:
    # Write enabled list to storage account
    print("Writing enabled list to VM latest path")
    vm_enable_df.toPandas().to_csv(enable_path, index=False)

    # Write disabled list to storage account
    print("Writing disabled list to VM latest path")
    vm_disable_df.toPandas().to_csv(disable_path, index=False)

    print("Update VM deployment activity log")
    # Compute updated activity log and write back to file
    activity_path = 'abfss://win-activity-v2@hubautomation.dfs.core.windows.net/activity.csv'
    activity_df = compute_activity_log_entry(activity_path)
    activity_df.toPandas().to_csv(activity_path, index=False)
# Output 'should_run' indication when running in pipeline
